entries.meaning: The introduction of unrelated breeding stock to an existing population, especially one which is inbred or homogeneous. [from 19th c.]
examples: Their two sons, Joseph I and Charles VI went still further in their pursuit of an out-cross by both marrying princesses from the Guelph house of Brunswick.

entries.meaning: A plant or animal produced by such methods. [from 20th c.]

verbs.description: outcross (third-person singular simple present outcrosses, present participle outcrossing, simple past and past participle outcrossed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to crossbreed different strains of a plant or animal. [from 20th c.]
